articles.headline: As Stocks Gyrate, It’s Time to Measure Your Risk Tolerance
articles.snippet: Knowing how much risk you can stomach will help you respond to market turmoil. Two companies have provided readers with tests to measure their risk.
articles.abstract: Knowing how much risk you can stomach will help you respond to market turmoil. Two companies have provided readers with tests to measure their risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time you got to know yourself a little better.

articles.headline: Republicans Fire Up Immigration Talk Heading Into South Carolina
articles.snippet: Party leaders had hoped some of the most provocative speech would have subsided by now, but the battle lines on the issue have only deepened.
articles.abstract: Party leaders had hoped some of the most provocative speech would have subsided by now, but the battle lines on the issue have only deepened.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — The Republican presidential race has erupted in an incendiary new round of attacks over immigration, laying the groundwork in South Carolina for a monthslong fight that is likely to amplify hard-line talk about border security and migrants before a national audience.

articles.headline: Takata Discarded Evidence of Airbag Ruptures as Early as 2000
articles.snippet: A former Takata airbag engineer testified that the company’s airbags began rupturing in internal testing as many as 16 years ago.
articles.abstract: A former Takata airbag engineer testified that the company’s airbags began rupturing in internal testing as many as 16 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As the safety crisis surrounding Takata’s airbags that are prone to rupture has mushroomed, the Japanese auto supplier has insisted that the propellant in its airbags is safe.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: John Dickerson, Molded by News Legends, Hones His Skills at CBS
articles.snippet: Mr. Dickerson, the host of “Face the Nation,” could face his biggest audience yet when he moderates the Republican debate in South Carolina.
articles.abstract: Mr. Dickerson, the host of “Face the Nation,” could face his biggest audience yet when he moderates the Republican debate in South Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the standards of Sunday morning news shows, the handoff of the anchor’s position on “Face the Nation” on CBS was really quite peaceful.

articles.headline: Gearing Up for the Cloud, AT&T Tells Its Workers: Adapt, or Else
articles.snippet: Randall Stephenson, the chief, sees a need to retrain his 280,000 employees — like his older brother, who fixes the lines — to compete with the likes of Google.
articles.abstract: Randall Stephenson, the chief, sees a need to retrain his 280,000 employees — like his older brother, who fixes the lines — to compete with the likes of Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Thirty-four years ago, Kevin Stephenson got his younger brother, Randall, a job with the telephone company.

articles.headline: The Commute of the Future? Ford Is Working on It
articles.snippet: The design firm Ideo, which helped design the computer mouse, has been enlisted by Ford to shadow commuters and see how they get where they’re going: by car, bus, foot or Uber.
articles.abstract: The design firm Ideo, which helped design the computer mouse, has been enlisted by Ford to shadow commuters and see how they get where they’re going: by car, bus, foot or Uber.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a brisk October day in Chicago, a few employees from the design firm Ideo left their office and headed to Knife & Tine, a restaurant about four miles away. The goal, besides lunch, was to complete the journey within 45 minutes, on a budget of just $10 for the whole group, all while carrying bulky shopping bags.

articles.headline: Antonin Scalia, Justice on the Supreme Court, Dies at 79
articles.snippet: Justice Scalia, whose legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a conservative leader, was found dead on Saturday in Texas.
articles.abstract: Justice Scalia, whose legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a conservative leader, was found dead on Saturday in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia, whose transformative legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a leader of a conservative intellectual renaissance in his three decades on the Supreme Court, was found dead on Saturday at a resort in West Texas. He was 79.

articles.headline: Battle Begins Over Naming Next Justice
articles.snippet: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday immediately set off a partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as Senate Republicans called on President Obama to let his successor fill the seat.
articles.abstract: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday immediately set off a partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as Senate Republicans called on President Obama to let his successor fill the seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday set off an immediate partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as President Obama vowed to nominate a successor and Senate Republicans called on him to let the next president fill the seat.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: In Republican Debate, Jeb Bush Attacks Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief.
articles.abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief during a contentious and sometimes nasty Republican presidential debate in Greenville, S.C., on Saturday, a week before a crucial primary in the state.

articles.headline: Syrian Officer Gave a View of War. ISIS Came, and Silence Followed.
articles.snippet: Abu al-Majd, who fought with government forces, also struck up a relationship with Times correspondents. Then he was sent to Palmyra, and disappeared.
articles.abstract: Abu al-Majd, who fought with government forces, also struck up a relationship with Times correspondents. Then he was sent to Palmyra, and disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ours was an unusual, sometimes operatic, correspondence that unfolded over more than a year. Abu al-Majd, a Syrian police officer who was being deployed more and more often like a soldier, texted at all hours, sending news from the front lines and grumbling about boring, sunbaked patrols, his complaints sometimes punctuated by expressions of terror, pride or doubt.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: After Antonin Scalia’s Death, Fierce Battle Lines Emerge
articles.snippet: The debate over who should replace Justice Scalia on the Supreme Court created a complicated calculus for both the Senate and President Obama.
articles.abstract: The debate over who should replace Justice Scalia on the Supreme Court created a complicated calculus for both the Senate and President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An epic Washington political battle took shape on Sunday after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia as Senate Republicans dug in and said they would refuse to act on any Supreme Court nomination by President Obama. But the White House vowed to select a nominee within weeks.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Malawi Gets Its First Grammy Nomination, With Album by Prison Inmates
articles.snippet: The work has been an unexpected boon for the tiny African nation and now goes up against the works of well-known artists in the world music category.
articles.abstract: The work has been an unexpected boon for the tiny African nation and now goes up against the works of well-known artists in the world music category.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZOMBA, Malawi — Old, overcrowded and unsanitary, the maximum-security Zomba prison holds murderers, robbers, rapists — and Grammy-nominated singers.

articles.headline: With Death of Antonin Scalia, an Already Volatile Campaign Erupts
articles.snippet: An unpredictable election that had pitted grass-roots activists against traditional party leaders is suddenly erupting into a rare battle royale for control of every branch of government.
articles.abstract: An unpredictable election that had pitted grass-roots activists against traditional party leaders is suddenly erupting into a rare battle royale for control of every branch of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the hours after she learned about the death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday, Hillary Clinton intended to confine her response to a 79-word statement extending thoughts and prayers to his family and praising his “energy and passion” on the bench.

articles.headline: Scalia’s Absence Is Likely to Alter Court’s Major Decisions This Term
articles.snippet: Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the remaining justices, as some cases could result in 4-to-4 deadlocks, and strengthen the Supreme Court’s liberal wing.
articles.abstract: Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the remaining justices, as some cases could result in 4-to-4 deadlocks, and strengthen the Supreme Court’s liberal wing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the Supreme Court’s eight remaining justices for the rest of the court’s term, probably change the outcomes of some major cases and, for the most part, amplify the power of its four-member liberal wing.
